title: 111_s3920
content: The Commission on Economic Security is established. The Economic Security Defense Act of 2010 is established to address the vulnerabilities in the economy highlighted by the recent financial crisis. Malevolent actors are able to exploit the interconnectedness of the economy, as shown in a Department of Defense war game won by a group representing the Government of China. Prominent experts warn of cybersecurity threats and economic warfare capabilities developed by foreign governments, such as China's economic warfare bureau. Al Qaeda and other terrorist groups are focusing on destabilizing financial systems post the 2008 Lehman Brothers collapse. Experts have warned of cybersecurity threats and other dangers that could disrupt financial institutions and critical infrastructure like the national power grid. A commission called the "Security Threats to Financial Markets and Economic Recovery Commission" has been established to examine these threats and develop legislative recommendations to address potential risks from state and non-state actors, as well as vulnerabilities in financial markets. The "Security Threats to Financial Markets and Economic Recovery Commission" is examining cybersecurity threats and vulnerabilities in financial markets. Legislative recommendations may include reforms to address gaps in capabilities, strengthen market security, and tackle systemic weaknesses. The Commission will submit a report to Congress and the President by September 1, 2011, detailing its activities, findings on public preferences from town hall hearings, and any reforms addressing financial systemic weaknesses. The Commission will submit legislative recommendations to Congress and the President within 60 days of submitting a full report, addressing issues identified in public hearings and proposing policy options. The recommendations must be approved by at least 10 members of the Commission. The Commission, composed of 20 voting members and 3 nonvoting members, aims to achieve financial market security, address expert suggestions, and meet criteria outlined in the Commission report. The Commission, consisting of 20 voting members and 3 nonvoting members, includes appointees from the private sector and the executive branch for advisory purposes. The Commission consists of 20 voting members and 3 nonvoting members, with 2 cochairpersons designated by key leaders from the House and Senate, ensuring bipartisan representation. Each appointing authority can appoint 1-2 Members of Congress to the Commission. Members of the Commission do not receive compensation, but they do receive travel expenses. The Commission meets upon the call of the chairperson or a majority of its voting members, with a quorum of six voting members required for meetings. Staffing rules are determined by the Commission. The cochairpersons of the Commission may appoint up to 3 staff members, who are exempt from certain civil service laws and cannot be paid more than the maximum rate of pay for a GS-14 position. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. The Commission has the authority to conduct investigations, take testimony, administer oaths, and use the United States mails. They can also request administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services. The Commission may enter into contracts, accept gifts, and dispose of donations to carry out its duties under this Act. Funding for the Commission will be provided through discretionary appropriations, and it will terminate 60 days after submitting its legislative proposal to Congress.
